metadata.description: Valley Tonga as spoken in Southern Province of Zambia

examples: Good morning - Mwabuka buti
Good morning everyone - Mwabuka buti bonse
How are you - Muli buti
how are you.culturalContext: Standard greeting in Tonga culture. 'Muli buti' is formal, 'uli buti' is informal.

examples: I want bread - Ndiyanda cinkwa
Fresh bread - Cinkwa cipya
bread.culturalContext: Common food item in Tonga communities

examples: How are you young man? - Uli buti mulombe?
Good morning, how are you young man? - Mwabuka buti, uli buti mulombe?
how are you young man.culturalContext: Respectful greeting to a young male, acknowledging their youth status
how are you young man.usage: Common greeting phrase used when addressing a young man or boy

examples: How are you young girl? - Uli buti musimbi?
Good morning, how are you young girl? - Mwabuka buti, uli buti musimbi?
how are you young girl.culturalContext: Respectful greeting to a young female, acknowledging their youth status
how are you young girl.usage: Common greeting phrase used when addressing a young girl or female child

examples: Where can I find mango trees? - Nkujana masamu amango?
I want to know where I can find mango trees - Ndiyanda kuziba nkujana masamu amango
where can I find mango trees.culturalContext: Mangoes are popular fruits in Zambia, though not native to the region. They were introduced during colonial times and are now widely grown in Southern Province.
where can I find mango trees.usage: Useful phrase when looking for specific fruit trees or resources in a new area

examples: How are you? - Mwapona?
Hello, how are you? - Mwabuka, mwapona?
how are you (greeting).culturalContext: Common informal greeting in Tonga culture

examples: I am fine - Kabotu
How are you? Fine - Mwapona? Kabotu
good, fine (answer).culturalContext: Standard response to greetings inquiring about one's wellbeing

examples: Thank you - Twalumba
Thank you for helping me - Twalumba kundigwasya
thank you.culturalContext: Expression of gratitude in Tonga culture

examples: Cheers! - Twalumba!
cheers.culturalContext: Used during toasts or as an expression of good wishes

examples: Good afternoon - Mwayusa
Good afternoon everyone - Mwayusa bonse
Good night - Kwasiya
Good night, sleep well - Kwasiya, koona kabotu
good night.culturalContext: Evening farewell greeting in Tonga culture

examples: Welcome - Mwabonwa
Welcome to our home - Mwabonwa kung'anda yesu
welcome.culturalContext: Expression of hospitality in Tonga culture

examples: You are very welcome - Mwabonwa bassa noose
very welcome.culturalContext: Expression of enthusiastic hospitality in Tonga culture

examples: I need water - Ndiyanda meenda
Clean water - Meenda asalala
The food is ready - Chakulya chalibambidwe
I want some food - Ndiyanda chakulya
food.culturalContext: Essential aspect of daily life and hospitality in Tonga culture

examples: Let's eat - Atuliye
I want to eat - Ndiyanda kuliya
eat.culturalContext: Eating is often a communal activity in Tonga culture

examples: I want to drink water - Ndiyanda kunywa meenda
Let's drink - Atunywe
Let's go and eat - Tukalye
Let's go and eat now - Tukalye lino
let's go and eat.culturalContext: Eating together is an important social activity in Tonga culture

examples: Let's go - Atwende
Let's go home - Atwende kung'anda
let's go.culturalContext: Common phrase used for group movement or activities

examples: Yes, I understand - Iyii, ndamvwa
Do you want food? Yes - Uyanda chakulya? Iyii
No, I don't want - Pepe, nsiyandi
Are you hungry? No - Wafwa nzala? Pepe
There is nothing here - Takwepe awa
What did you find? Nothing - Wajana nzi? Takwepe
nothing.culturalContext: Used to indicate absence or emptiness

examples: Go to the market - Koya kumusika
I want to go - Ndiyanda koya
go.culturalContext: Basic movement verb in daily communication

examples: I want to go - Ime ndiyanda koya
I am here - Ime ndilawa
i.culturalContext: First person singular pronoun in Tonga

examples: You are late - Iwe waceceka
Where are you going? - Iwe uya kuli?
you.culturalContext: Second person singular pronoun in Tonga

examples: We are going to town - Iswe tuya kumunzi
We want food - Iswe tuyanda chakulya
we.culturalContext: First person plural pronoun in Tonga, emphasizing group identity

examples: What's your name? - Nduwe ni?
Hello, what's your name? - Mwabuka, nduwe ni?
what's your name?.culturalContext: Common phrase when meeting someone new in Tonga culture

examples: My name is John - Ndime John
What's your name? My name is Mary - Nduwe ni? Ndime Mary
my name is.culturalContext: Standard response to name inquiries in Tonga culture

examples: I want to drink beer - Ndiyanda kunywa bukoko
We have beer at home - Tuli abukoko kung'anda
beer.culturalContext: Traditional and commercial beers play a role in social gatherings in Tonga culture

examples: When will you start to play? - Mutalika cindinzi kusobana?
The children asked, when will you start to play? - Bana babuzya, mutalika cindinzi kusobana?
when will you start to play?.culturalContext: Used in context of games, music, or sports activities
when will you start to play?.usage: Inquiry about starting time of an activity

examples: Come here please - Kweza caamba
Child, come here - Mwana, kweza
come here.culturalContext: Common directive used in daily communication

examples: I am looking for my keys - Ndilanga makiyi angu
What are you looking at? - Ulanga nzi?
looking.culturalContext: Common action verb in daily conversation

examples: Drink some water - Nywa meenda
I want to drink coffee - Ndiyanda kunywa kkofi
I will go today - Ndilakoya sunu
Today is hot - Sunu kupya
today.culturalContext: Basic time reference in daily communication

examples: I will come tomorrow - Ndilakuza junza
Until tomorrow - Kusikila junza
tomorrow.culturalContext: Common time reference used in planning and arrangements

examples: We will harvest the day after tomorrow - Tulatebula zona
Not tomorrow but the day after tomorrow - Kutali junza pele zona
the day after tomorrow.culturalContext: Used in planning activities or events in the near future

examples: The child is sleeping - Mwana uloona
Where is your child? - Mwana wako uli kuli?
child.culturalContext: Children are highly valued in Tonga culture and family structures

examples: My brother is coming - Mukulana wangu uleza
I live with my brother - Ndikkala amukulana wangu
brother.culturalContext: Family relationships are particularly important in Tonga culture

examples: My mother is cooking - Bama balakupika
Where is your mother? - Bama bako bali kuli?
mother.culturalContext: Mothers hold a special place of respect in Tonga family structure

examples: My father works in town - Ndende wangu ulabeleka mumunzi
This is my father - Oyu ndende wangu
father.culturalContext: Fathers are traditional authority figures in Tonga family structure

examples: My uncle is visiting today - Tatalenzi wangu ulaswaya sunu
I respect my uncle - Ndilacitya tatalenzi wangu
uncle.culturalContext: Extended family relationships are important in Tonga culture, with uncles often playing significant roles in children's upbringing

examples: Goodbye, see you tomorrow - Mucaale kabotu, nzokubona junza
See you tomorrow at school - Nzokubona junza kucikolo
see you tomorrow.culturalContext: Common farewell phrase indicating expectation of future meeting

examples: The ladies are singing - Banakazi balaimba
Good morning ladies - Mwabuka buti banakazi
ladies.culturalContext: Used to address or refer to a group of women in Tonga society

examples: The men are working in the field - Balumi babeleka mumuunda
Good morning men - Mwabuka buti balumi
men.culturalContext: Used to address or refer to a group of men in Tonga society

examples: Her eyes are beautiful - Meso akwe mabotu
My eyes hurt - Meso angu alacisa
eyes.culturalContext: Body part commonly referenced in daily conversation

examples: His nose is big - Impemo yakwe mpati
My nose is running - Impemo yangu ilayeenda
nose.culturalContext: Body part commonly referenced in daily conversation

examples: Brush your teeth - Kusanzya meno ako
My teeth are white - Meno angu atuba
teeth.culturalContext: Body part commonly referenced in daily conversation and hygiene practices

examples: I think it will rain - Ndiyeya kuti ilanooka
What do you think? - Uyeya buti?
think.culturalContext: Common cognitive verb used in decision-making and opinions

examples: The children run to school - Bana balacijana kucikolo
I want to run - Ndiyanda kucijana
run.culturalContext: Basic action verb used to describe rapid movement

examples: I want to talk to you - Ndiyanda kuwambula ayebo
They are talking about the harvest - Balawambula atwebula
talk.culturalContext: Communication is valued in Tonga culture for sharing information and maintaining community bonds

examples: The children laugh - Bana balaseka
Why are you laughing? - Nkaambanzi ulaseka?
laugh.culturalContext: Expression of joy or amusement in social settings

examples: I ride a bicycle to work - Ndulanyampula camuntendelele kubeleka
My bicycle is broken - Camuntendelele cangu calityoka
bicycle.culturalContext: Important mode of transportation in rural areas of Zambia

examples: He bought a new car - Waula imota mpya
The car is fast - Imota ileenda canguzu
car.culturalContext: Modern transportation viewed as a symbol of status in some communities

examples: I have five goats - Ndijisi mpongo zisanu
The goat is eating grass - Mpongo ilalya bwizu
goat.culturalContext: Goats are important livestock in Tonga communities, used for meat, milk, and traditional ceremonies

examples: We have many sheep - Tuli aimbelele zinji
The sheep are in the field - Imbelele zili mumuunda
sheep.culturalContext: Livestock important for wool, meat, and in some cases ceremonial purposes

examples: Goodbye, see you tomorrow - Mucaale kabotu, nzokubona junza
I must go now, goodbye - Ndeleede kuunka lino, mucaale kabotu
goodbye.culturalContext: Common farewell expression wishing the other person to stay well

examples: Add more water - Yungizya meenda ambi
I want to add sugar - Ndiyanda kuyungizya shuka
add.culturalContext: Common action in cooking, mathematics, and daily activities

examples: The boys are fighting - Balombe balalwaana
Don't fight - Mutailwaani
fight.culturalContext: Traditional Tonga culture generally discourages fighting and promotes peaceful conflict resolution

examples: I am happy - Ndilakondwa
Are you happy? - Ulakondwa?
happy.culturalContext: Expression of emotional state highly valued in social interactions

examples: This is my friend - Oyu mwenzuma wangu
I am going with my friend - Ndiya amwenzuma wangu
friend.culturalContext: Friendship is highly valued in Tonga culture, with social bonds forming an important part of community life

examples: We need more mealie meal - Tuyanda buusu bumbi
The mealie meal is finished - Buusu bwamana
mealie meal.culturalContext: Staple food made from ground maize, essential in Tonga diet for making nshima (the staple food)

examples: The porridge is hot - Lweele lula kupya
I eat porridge for breakfast - Ndilalya lweele kucitanzi
porridge.culturalContext: Common breakfast food especially for children, often made from mealie meal

examples: We work in the field - Tubeleka mumuunda
The field is large - Muunda mupati
field.culturalContext: Agriculture is central to traditional Tonga livelihood, with fields being important family assets

examples: Our fields are fertile - Myunda yesu mibotu
The fields need rain - Myunda iyanda mvula
fields.culturalContext: Plural form of field, reflecting the importance of land and agriculture in Tonga society

examples: The children are at school - Bana bali kucikolo
Our school is new - Cikolo cesu cipya
school.culturalContext: Education is increasingly valued in Tonga communities for advancement and opportunity

examples: I am learning Tonga - Ndilakwiiya chiTonga
Learning is important - Kwiiya kulayandika
learning.culturalContext: Traditional Tonga education involved learning practical skills and cultural knowledge from elders, now formal education is also valued

examples: He has malaria - Ujisi malangazuba
Malaria is common in rainy season - Malangazuba ulajanika muciindi camvula
malaria.culturalContext: Common disease in Zambia's Southern Province that has significant impact on communities

examples: We want peace - Tuyanda lumuno
Let us live in peace - Atukkale mulumuno
peace.culturalContext: Highly valued concept in Tonga society, reflecting the community's emphasis on harmonious relationships

examples: I'm going to work - Ndiya kumulimo
The work is difficult - Mulimo ulikattontola
work.culturalContext: Work ethic is valued in Tonga culture, especially agricultural labor which is central to traditional livelihoods

examples: The mountain is high - Cilundu cileelede
They live near the mountain - Bakkala munsi acilundu
mountain.culturalContext: Geographical features play important roles in Tonga culture, sometimes holding spiritual significance

examples: I want one banana - Ndiyanda ibanana kamwi
One person came - Muntu kamwi wakasika
one.culturalContext: Numbers are important in daily transactions and traditional counting systems

examples: I have two children - Ndijisi bana tubili
Give me two mangoes - Ndipe mangos tubili
two.culturalContext: Basic number used in counting and daily transactions

examples: I need three eggs - Ndiyanda maji tutatu
There are three houses - Kuli maanda tutatu
three.culturalContext: Basic number used in counting and daily transactions

examples: Four women are coming - Banakazi tune baleza
I want four tomatoes - Ndiyanda matimati tune
four.culturalContext: Basic number used in counting and daily transactions

examples: We have five goats - Tujisi mpongo musanu
Five days ago - Mazuba musanu akainda
five.culturalContext: Basic number used in counting and daily transactions

examples: I need six plates - Ndiyanda mapleti musanu akamwi
Six people are waiting - Bantu musanu akamwi balindila
six.culturalContext: In Tonga counting system, six is represented as 'five and one'

examples: I have ten fingers - Ndijisi minwe ikumi
Ten days - Mazuba ikumi
ten.culturalContext: Base number in the decimal counting system used in Tonga

examples: She is sixteen years old - Ujisi myaka ikumi amusanu akamwi
Sixteen cows - Ng'ombe ikumi amusanu akamwi
sixteen.culturalContext: In Tonga counting system, sixteen is expressed as 'ten and five and one'

examples: I need twenty kwacha - Ndiyanda makwacha makumi obile
Twenty people came - Bantu makumi obile bakasika
twenty.culturalContext: In Tonga counting system, twenty is expressed as 'tens two'

examples: The journey takes thirty minutes - Lweendo lutola mamineti makumi atatu
Thirty days - Mazuba makumi atatu
thirty.culturalContext: In Tonga counting system, thirty is expressed as 'tens three'

examples: One hundred kwacha - Makwacha mwanda
One hundred people attended - Bantu mwanda bakasika
one hundred.culturalContext: Large number used in counting and significant transactions

examples: One thousand kwacha - Makwacha cuulu
More than one thousand people - Kwiinda bantu cuulu
one thousand.culturalContext: Large number used in significant transactions and referring to large quantities

examples: I want to write a letter - Ndiyanda kulemba lugwalo
The children are writing - Bana balalemba
write.culturalContext: Literacy has gained importance in Tonga communities with the spread of formal education

examples: I'm waiting for the bus - Ndilindila bbaasi
The bus is coming - Bbaasi ileza
bus.culturalContext: Important mode of transportation connecting rural communities to urban centers in Zambia

examples: Tell me the truth - Ndambila ciini
He always speaks the truth - Lyoonse ulawamba ciini
truth.culturalContext: Truth-telling is valued in Tonga culture as a mark of integrity and character

examples: I want to eat - Ndiyanda kulya
Let's go to eat - Atwende kulya
to eat.culturalContext: Eating together is an important social activity in Tonga culture

examples: Thank you, but I have eaten - Twalumba, pele ndalya kale
Have you eaten? Yes, I have eaten - Walya? Iyii, ndalya kale
i have eaten.culturalContext: Common response when offered food after one has already eaten

examples: They like to fight - Bayanda kulwana
Don't fight - Utakulwani
to fight.culturalContext: Conflict resolution in Tonga culture traditionally emphasizes peaceful solutions over fighting

examples: I am happy to see you - Ndilakukondwa kukubona
The children are happy - Bana balakondwa
to be happy.culturalContext: Expressions of joy and happiness are valued in social interactions

examples: Where are you going? - Muya kuli?
Where are you going so early? - Muya kuli cifumo boobu?
where are you going?.culturalContext: Common greeting question used in daily encounters

examples: I want to talk to you about something - Ndiyanda kwambula ayebo atala aceeco
Can I talk to you? I want to talk to you - Ndilakonzya kwambula ayebo? Ndiyanda kwambula ayebo
i want to talk to you.culturalContext: Direct communication is valued in Tonga culture, especially for important matters

examples: The place is nice - Indawo nimbotu loko
I like this place, the place is nice - Ndiyanda aawa, indawo nimbotu loko
the place is nice.culturalContext: Appreciating and acknowledging the beauty of a place is common in Tonga expressions

examples: The children like to run - Bana bayanda kucijana
He can run fast - Ulakonzya kucijana canguzu
to run.culturalContext: Physical activity reflecting ability and energy

examples: The plant will die without water - Cisamu cilafwa kakutakwe meenda
Many people died from the disease - Bantu banji bakafwa kuzwaa kumulwazi
to die.culturalContext: Death is treated with great reverence in Tonga culture, with specific rituals for honoring the deceased

examples: Birds fly - Bayuni balakuluka
I want to fly to Lusaka - Ndiyanda kuuluka kuya ku Lusaka
to fly.culturalContext: Traditional understanding of flight was limited to birds, but now includes modern transportation

examples: He is acting mad - Ulikuliita mbuli kupenga
Don't drive like you're mad - Utayendesyi mbuli kupenga
to be mad.culturalContext: Mental health conditions traditionally viewed differently in Tonga culture than in Western medicine

examples: Are you telling the truth? - Masimpe?
Are you really telling the truth? - Masimpe ncobeni?
are you telling the truth?.culturalContext: Truth-telling is valued, and this phrase is used to confirm honesty

examples: His greediness is well known - Bulangazi bwakwe bulizibinkene
Greediness leads to problems - Bulangazi bulatola kumapenzi
greediness.culturalContext: Greediness is typically viewed negatively in Tonga culture, which values sharing and community support

examples: He has a lot of property - Ujisi lubono lunji
The wealth belongs to the family - Lubono ndulwa mukwasyi
property/wealth.culturalContext: Traditionally, wealth in Tonga culture was measured in livestock and land rather than money

examples: She is working in the garden - Ulabeleka muincelela
The vegetables in the garden are ready - Insalasya muincelela zyalibambilwa
garden.culturalContext: Gardens (especially vegetable gardens) are important for household food security in Tonga communities

examples: Take the foot path to get there faster - Kunyampula inzila kuti usike canguzu
The foot path goes through the field - Inzila ilainda mumuunda
foot path.culturalContext: Foot paths are common in rural areas, connecting villages, fields, and water sources

examples: The road to Livingstone is good - Mugwagwa wakulaya ku Livingstone mulibotu
They are building a new road - Balayaka mugwagwa mupya
road.culturalContext: Road infrastructure development has changed mobility patterns in Tonga communities

examples: The journey was long - Lweendo lwakalampa
I'm preparing for the journey - Ndilalibambila lweendo
journey.culturalContext: Journeys traditionally had cultural significance, with rituals for safe travel

examples: He grows tobacco - Ulasimba polya
The tobacco is ready for harvest - Polya walibambilwa kutebulwa
tobacco.culturalContext: Tobacco has been both a cash crop and used in certain traditional practices

examples: The clothes are covered in dirt - Zisamo zyazwide itombe
Wash away the dirt - Kusanzya itombe
dirt.culturalContext: Cleanliness is valued in Tonga culture, especially personal cleanliness

examples: I am resting after work - Ndilakuulyookezya kumana beleka
He is resting under the tree - Ulakuulyookezya munsi amusamu
resting.culturalContext: Rest is valued, especially after physical labor which is common in agricultural communities

examples: He is smoking a cigarette - Ulafweba kandundu
I don't want a cigarette - Nsiyandi kandundu
cigarette.culturalContext: Modern cigarettes as distinct from traditional tobacco usage

examples: The village has no access to clean water - Munzi taukwejisi kusikika kumeenda asalala
We need access to the market - Tuyanda kusikika kumusika
access.culturalContext: Access to resources is an important consideration in rural Tonga communities

examples: They believe it's a bad omen - Balasyoma kuti malweza
The crow is seen as a bad omen - Kalukungu ulalangwa kuti malweza
bad omen.culturalContext: Traditional beliefs include various signs that foretell negative events

examples: Look at yourself in the mirror - Kulilanga muciboniboni
The mirror is broken - Ciboniboni califundulika
mirror.culturalContext: Traditional mirrors were made of polished metal or still water before glass mirrors arrived

examples: I'm watching television - Ndilalanga cipekupeku
The television is broken - Cipekupeku califundulika
television.culturalContext: Modern technology that has been incorporated into Tonga vocabulary, reflecting cultural adaptation to new technologies

examples: Poverty is a problem in rural areas - Bucete mbupati muzisi zyamunsi
They are fighting poverty - Balalwana abucete
poverty.culturalContext: Concept with important social implications in Tonga communities, where traditional support systems often help mitigate extreme poverty

examples: I made a promise - Ndakacita cisyomezyo
Keep your promise - Kubamba cisyomezyo cako
promise.culturalContext: In Tonga culture, keeping one's word and promises is highly valued and reflects on character and integrity

examples: Show me the evidence - Nditondezye bukamboni
There is no evidence - Takwe bukamboni
evidence.culturalContext: In traditional Tonga dispute resolution, evidence was important in village court proceedings

examples: Education is a right - Lwiiyo nduceelelo
Everyone has a right to healthcare - Muntu woonse ujisi ceelelo kumbungano
right.culturalContext: Concept of rights has evolved in Tonga society with changing political and social structures

examples: I'll come next week - Ndilakuza inviki iicilila
It's been a week - Yakaba inviki
week.culturalContext: Time measurement important for organizing activities and social events

examples: I will go on Monday - Ndilakuya muvulo
Monday is a busy day - Muvulo izuba lyakubela milimo minji
monday.culturalContext: First day of the week in modern work and school schedules

examples: The meeting is on Tuesday - Muswaangano uli bwabili
I will see you on Tuesday - Ndilakubona bwabili
tuesday.culturalContext: Second day of the week in the modern calendar

examples: Come on Wednesday - Kusika bwatatu
Wednesday is a market day - Bwatatu ndizuba lyamusika
wednesday.culturalContext: Third day of the week in the modern calendar

examples: The doctor comes on Thursday - Dokotela ulasika bwane
Thursday is my busy day - Bwane ndizuba lyangu lyamilimo
thursday.culturalContext: Fourth day of the week in the modern calendar

examples: I get paid on Friday - Ndilalibbigwa mali bwasanu
Friday is the last work day - Bwasanu ndizuba lyamamanino lyabeleka
friday.culturalContext: Fifth day of the week in the modern calendar, often culturally significant as end of work week

examples: We go to the market on Saturday - Tulaya kumusika mugibelo
Saturday is a rest day - Mugibelo ndizuba lyakulyookezya
saturday.culturalContext: Important day for markets and social gatherings in many Tonga communities

examples: We go to church on Sunday - Tulaya kucikombelo nsondo
Sunday is a day of worship - Nsondo ndizuba lyakukomba
sunday.culturalContext: Day of religious worship for many in Tonga communities, reflecting influence of Christianity

examples: Where are you coming from? - Mwazwida kuli?
Where are you coming from so late? - Mwazwida kuli ciindi cili boobu?
where are you coming from?.culturalContext: Common greeting question in Tonga interactions, showing interest in the other person's movements

examples: May I ask your name? - Ndilombwa kubuzya zina lyako?
May I ask you something? - Ndilombwa kubuzya cintu?
may i ask?.culturalContext: Polite formulation showing respect when making inquiries in Tonga culture

examples: When are we going to arrive at the village? - Ino tusike lili kumunzi?
I want to know when are we going to arrive - Ndiyanda kuziba ino tusike lili
when are we going to arrive?.culturalContext: Common question during travel, especially important when journeys may be long and unpredictable

examples: How far is it to Livingstone? - Nkule buti kulaya ku Livingstone?
How far is it to the river? - Nkule buti kulaya mulonga?
how far is it?.culturalContext: Important question for planning travel in areas where distances may be significant and transportation limited

examples: Is it getting close to the village? - Kwafwiimpa kumunzi?
Are we getting close? - Kwafwiimpa?
is it getting close?.culturalContext: Common question during journeys to gauge remaining travel time

examples: Are you staying for good? - Ulakukaalila limwi?
I'm staying for good in this village - Ndilakukaalila limwi mumunzi oyu
staying for good.culturalContext: Concept reflecting the significance of permanent settlement in a community, which has social implications in Tonga culture

examples: I'm hungry, let's eat - Ndafwa nzala, atulye
Are you hungry? Yes, I'm hungry - Wafwa nzala? Iyii, ndafwa nzala
i'm hungry.culturalContext: Direct expression of physical need, common in daily conversation

examples: I'm thirsty, I need water - Ndafwa nyota, ndiyanda meenda
Are you thirsty? - Wafwa nyota?
i'm thirsty.culturalContext: Direct expression of physical need, common in daily conversation

examples: Let's go home - Tweende kung'anda
It's late, let's go - Ciindi cainda, tweende
lets go.culturalContext: Common phrase used to initiate movement or departure

examples: I'm going to the shop - Ndiya kucintolo
The shop is closed - Cintolo calajala
shop/store.culturalContext: Commercial establishments that have become central to modern Tonga communities

examples: He won one million kwacha - Wakabbanga makwacha kaulunzuma
It costs one million - Cilatula kaulunzuma
one million.culturalContext: Large number reflecting modern economic concepts and currency denominations

examples: She is in the hospital - Uli mucibbadela
The hospital is far from here - Cibbadela cilakule kuzwa aawa
hospital.culturalContext: Modern medical facilities that complement traditional healing practices in contemporary Tonga society

examples: There are rumours about the chief - Kuli mavwambukila atala amwami
Don't spread rumours - Utanyampuli mavwambukila
rumours.culturalContext: In Tonga culture, spreading rumours is generally discouraged as it can disrupt community harmony

examples: Put it in the bag - Kubikka mucibbeke
I need a new bag - Ndiyanda cibbeke cipya
bag.culturalContext: Traditional bags were often made from local materials like reeds or animal skins

examples: I'm going to the market - Ndiya kumusyika
The market is busy today - Musyika ulijisi bantu banji sunu
market.culturalContext: Markets are important centers for trade and social interaction in Tonga communities

examples: He was sent to prison - Wakatumwa kuntolongo
The prison is far from town - Ntolongo ilakule kuzwa kudolopo
prison.culturalContext: Formal incarceration system introduced during colonial period, different from traditional justice systems

examples: Follow the sign post - Kutobela cinkwankwani
The sign post shows the way to the village - Cinkwankwani cilatondezya nzila kuya kumunzi
sign post.culturalContext: Modern infrastructure element important for navigation, especially as roads and formal transportation networks developed

examples: He spoke with malice - Wakaambuula aluciso
There is malice in his heart - Kuli luciso mumoyo wakwe
malice.culturalContext: Negative character trait that is discouraged in traditional Tonga values, which emphasize community harmony

examples: We don't have electricity today - Tatukwe magesi sunu
The electricity is working now - Magesi akubeleka lino
electricity.culturalContext: Modern utility that has been incorporated into rural and urban Tonga communities, though access remains limited in some areas

examples: His father practiced polygamy - Taata wakwe wakabela mumaali
Polygamy is less common now - Maali tacicikonzyi lino
polygamy.culturalContext: Traditional Tonga family structure sometimes included polygamous marriages, though practices have changed with Western and Christian influences

examples: The elders spoke against immorality - Bakulukulu bakaamba akulyanankwela
Immorality destroys communities - Kulyanankwela kulainyonyoona mikwasyi
immorality.culturalContext: Concept tied to cultural values and social norms, with specific behaviors considered improper or disruptive to community harmony

examples: I'm going to town - Ndiya kudolopo
The town has many shops - Dolopo lijisi zintolo zinji
town.culturalContext: Urban settlements became more significant during colonial and post-colonial periods as administrative and commercial centers

examples: I was born in this village - Ndakazyalilwa mumuunzi oyu
Our village is near the river - Muunzi wesu uli munsi amulonga
village.culturalContext: Traditional settlement unit in Tonga society, often organized around extended family groups and under leadership of village headman

examples: I saw an aeroplane flying - Ndakabona ndeke kiuluka
He traveled by aeroplane - Wakainka andeke
aeroplane.culturalContext: Modern transportation technology that has been incorporated into Tonga vocabulary

examples: We fish in the lake - Tulasobela mulwizi
The lake is large - Lwizi ndupati
lake.culturalContext: Important geographical feature for Tonga communities, particularly those near Lake Kariba

examples: The river is flowing fast - Mulonga ulayenda canguzu
We get water from the river - Tulategwa meenda kumulonga
river.culturalContext: Rivers are vital water sources and have cultural significance in Tonga communities

examples: There are mosquitoes in the swamp - Kuli mankai mucizyiba
Don't go near the swamp - Utayandi munsi acizyiba
swamp.culturalContext: Wetland features that are important ecological areas but can also be associated with disease vectors like mosquitoes

examples: The ocean is vast - Lwaanje ndupati
Fish come from the ocean - Inswi zilazwa kulwaanje
ocean.culturalContext: Though Zambia is landlocked, the concept of ocean is known through education and travel

examples: Show me your registration card - Nditondezye citupa cako
I lost my registration card - Ndakasweekelwa citupa cangu
registration card.culturalContext: Modern administrative document important for official identification and citizenship verification

examples: I received a letter from my brother - Ndakatambula lugwalo kuzwa kuli mukwesu
Write a letter to the chief - Kulemba lugwalo kumwami
letter.culturalContext: Written communication that became important with literacy and postal services

examples: He used insults - Wakabelesya tusi
Don't respond to insults - Utavwuiyi kutusi
insult.culturalContext: Verbal insults are generally discouraged in Tonga culture which values respect and harmonious relationships

examples: It is a taboo to do that - Cili citondwa kucita ceeco
Breaking a taboo has consequences - Kutyola citondwa kuli amipindu
taboo.culturalContext: Taboos are important cultural boundaries in Tonga society, with specific prohibitions related to ancestors, certain foods, behaviors during specific times like pregnancy, and interactions between specific relations

examples: The boy is playing - Musankwa ulasobana
Call that boy - Koita oyo musankwa
boy.culturalContext: In Tonga culture, boys traditionally learn skills from male relatives and have specific roles in the community

examples: The girl is singing - Musimbi ulaimba
My sister has a baby girl - Mucizi wangu ujisi musimbi
girl.culturalContext: In Tonga culture, girls traditionally learn domestic skills from female relatives and have specific roles in the household and community

examples: He works as a driver - Ulabeleka mbuli namutekenya
The driver is sleeping - Namutekenya uloona
driver.culturalContext: Professional drivers have become important figures in connecting remote Tonga communities to urban centers

examples: Prostitutes work in the town - Bawaamu babeleka mudolopo
She was a prostitute before she married - Wakali mwaamu katana kukwatwa
prostitute.culturalContext: Traditionally stigmatized occupation that contradicts Tonga values of proper marriage and family relationships

examples: They caught the thief - Bakajata mubbi
Don't be a thief - Utabi mubbi
thief.culturalContext: Stealing is strongly condemned in Tonga culture which values honesty and respect for others' property

examples: He is a hard worker - Ngu mubelesi wakusyomeka
The workers are on strike - Babelesi bali pakuliimya
worker.culturalContext: Hard work and diligence are valued traits in Tonga society

examples: He is a rich person - Ngu muvwubi
The rich person built a school - Muvwubi wakayaka cikolo
rich person.culturalContext: Wealth traditionally measured in cattle and land; now also includes money and modern possessions. Wealthy people are expected to assist community members in need

examples: There is a white person in the village - Kuli mukuwa mumuunzi
She married a white person - Wakakwatwa amukuwa
white person.culturalContext: Term originating from colonial era, referring to Europeans or people of European descent

examples: My backbone hurts - Musana wangu ulacisa
The backbone supports the body - Musana ulajatizya mubili
backbone.culturalContext: Body part that is often referred to in contexts of physical labor, common in agricultural communities

examples: She tied a cloth around her waist - Wakaanga cisamo kucibuno
My waist is thin - Cibuno cangu cijokede
waist.culturalContext: Body part often referenced in traditional dress and dance context

examples: He injured his thigh - Wakaciswa cibelo
The thigh muscle is strong - Musinzo wacibelo nguyumu
thigh.culturalContext: Body part important in physical activities and traditional dance movements

examples: The mother is feeding the baby at her breast - Baama balakumunyonsya mwana kunkoolo
She felt pain in her breast - Wakumvwa kucisa munkolo
breast.culturalContext: Associated with motherhood and nurturing in Tonga culture

examples: I saw an animal in the bush - Ndakabona munyama musokwe
The animal is drinking water - Munyama ulanywa meenda
animal.culturalContext: Wildlife plays important roles in Tonga culture, featuring in stories, proverbs, and traditional knowledge

examples: The animals are grazing - Banyama balalya bwizu
We saw many animals - Twakabona banyama banji
animals.culturalContext: Collective term for wildlife that features prominently in Tonga oral traditions

examples: The men went to hunt - Balumi bakaya kuvwima
They hunt elephants - Balavwima nzovwu
to hunt.culturalContext: Traditional subsistence activity for many Tonga men, with associated rituals and customs

examples: The hyena laughs at night - Suntwe ulaseka mansiku
Hyenas are scavengers - Suntwe ulacula zyakulya zyabanyama bakafwa
hyena.culturalContext: Often featured in folklore as a trickster or cunning character

examples: The rabbit is fast - Sulwe ulaangu
We saw a rabbit in the garden - Twakabona sulwe muincelela
rabbit/hare.culturalContext: Common character in Tonga folktales, often portrayed as clever and quick-witted

examples: The leopard is hiding in the tree - Siluwe ulisisa mumusamu
The leopard's spots are beautiful - Mabala asiluwe mabotu
leopard.culturalContext: Respected and feared predator in Tonga regions, sometimes associated with leadership or royalty in folklore

examples: The buffalo is dangerous - Munyati ulayoosya
We saw a herd of buffalo - Twakabona butanga bwamunyati
buffalo.culturalContext: Considered one of the most dangerous wild animals, featuring in hunting stories and traditional warnings

examples: The elephant is big - Inzovwu mpati
Elephants have long trunks - Inzovwu zijisi mbombo zilamfu
elephant.culturalContext: Respected animal in Tonga culture, symbolizing strength and wisdom in many African traditions

examples: The cheetah runs fast - Malama ulacijanisya
We saw a cheetah hunting - Twakabona malama kavwima
cheetah.culturalContext: Known for its speed, the cheetah features in traditional stories about hunting and pursuit

examples: The kudu has large horns - Syambololo ujisi mpembe zipati
We hunted kudu - Twakavwima syambololo
kudu.culturalContext: Valued game animal in traditional Tonga hunting practices, with distinctive spiral horns

examples: The duiker is small - Insya ninjini
The duiker is hiding in the bush - Insya ilisisa musokwe
duiker.culturalContext: Small antelope commonly hunted for food in traditional Tonga subsistence practices

examples: Be careful of the snake - Kucenjela inzoka
The snake is long - Inzoka ndilamfu
snake.culturalContext: Often associated with spiritual beliefs and caution in Tonga culture, with specific types having different symbolic meanings

examples: The waterbuck lives near water - Mbabala ikkala munsi ameenda
We saw a waterbuck at the river - Twakabona mbabala kumulonga
waterbuck.culturalContext: Large antelope often found near water sources, featured in traditional hunting stories

examples: The eland is the largest antelope - Incengu ngo mpombwe mpati maningi
Elands travel in herds - Incengu zilyeenda mubutanga
eland.culturalContext: Highly valued game animal in traditional Tonga hunting, respected for its size and meat

examples: Wild dogs hunt in packs - Umpe ulavwima mutubunga
The wild dog is different from domestic dogs - Umpe uliimpene ambwa yesu
wild dog.culturalContext: Feared and respected predator known for pack hunting behavior in the wild

examples: The lion roars - Syuumbwa ulakulula
The lion is the king of beasts - Syuumbwa mwami wabanyama
lion.culturalContext: Symbol of strength and leadership in many African cultures including Tonga traditions

examples: The hippopotamus lives in the river - Civwubwe cikkala mumulonga
The hippopotamus is dangerous - Civwubwe cilayoosya
hippopotamus.culturalContext: Common in Zambian rivers and considered one of the most dangerous animals, featuring in traditional warnings and stories

examples: I will visit in January - Ndilaswaya mu Mukazimazyiba
January is the first month of the year - Mukazimazyiba mwezi mutaanzi wamwaka
january.culturalContext: First month of the year in the modern calendar, a rainy season month in Southern Zambia

examples: We planted in February - Twakasyanga mu Mulumi
February is a rainy month - Mulumi mwezi wamvula
february.culturalContext: Peak of the rainy season in Southern Zambia, important month for agricultural activities

examples: He was born in March - Wakazyalwa mu Miyoba
March is when we begin harvesting - Miyoba ciindi notutanguna kutebula
march.culturalContext: Month when early crops begin to mature in traditional Tonga agricultural calendar

examples: We will harvest in April - Tulatebula mu Mukubwekangala
April often has some late rains - Mukubwekangala ulakonzya kuba amvula yakumamanino
april.culturalContext: Month associated with major harvesting activities in Tonga agricultural calendar

examples: We finished harvesting in May - Twakamaninsya kutebula mu Kandakamanini
May is getting cooler - Kandakamanini kutalika kutontola
may.culturalContext: Month when harvesting is typically completed and temperatures begin to cool

examples: June is cold - Gandapati kula kutontola
We will have a ceremony in June - Tulaakuba amusamu mu Gandapati
june.culturalContext: Beginning of the cold season, when many traditional ceremonies take place after harvest

examples: July is windy - Kkunkumunamasamu kula amuwo
Trees lose leaves in July - Masamu alasowya matu mu Kkunkumunamasamu
july.culturalContext: Month whose name refers to the wind shaking trees, as this is typically a windy period

examples: August is still cold - Itwe ucitontola
We prepare fields in August - Tulabamba myuunda mu Itwe
august.culturalContext: Month when early field preparation may begin in preparation for the coming agricultural season

examples: September is getting hot - Ivwivwi kutalika kupya
Many trees flower in September - Masamu manji alakomenesya mu Ivwivwi
september.culturalContext: Month of warming temperatures when many indigenous trees flower before the rains

examples: October is very hot - Kavwumbi kupya loko
We wait for rain in October - Tulalindila mvula mu Kavwumbi
october.culturalContext: Hot season month when the first rains are anticipated, named for the dusty conditions

examples: The rains start in November - Mvula ilatalika mu Vwumbipati
We plant in November - Tulasyanga mu Vwumbipati
november.culturalContext: Month when the rainy season typically begins, signaling the start of the agricultural season

examples: December is rainy - Nalupale ulijisi mvula
We celebrate the new year in December - Tulakondwa mwaka mupya mu Nalupale
december.culturalContext: Month of significant rainfall and celebrations of the year's end and new year

examples: The rainy season is important for crops - Mainza alayandika kuzisyango
During the rainy season, the roads are muddy - Muciindi camainza, migwagwa ilaba antipa
rainy season.culturalContext: The most important season in the traditional Tonga calendar, associated with agricultural activities and growth

examples: The dry season is from May to October - Cilimo ulaba kuzwa mu Kandakamanini kusika ku Kavwumbi
We harvest during the dry season - Tulatebula muciindi cacilimo
dry season.culturalContext: Period after harvest when agricultural activities slow down and focus shifts to storage and preservation

examples: The cold season is from June to August - Mupeyo ulaba kuzwa mu Gandapati kusika ku Itwe
During the cold season, we sit around the fire - Muciindi camupeyo, tulakkala kumulilo
cold season.culturalContext: Period of lower temperatures when social activities move indoors and around fires

examples: The sun is hot - Zuba lipya
We dry food in the sun - Tulawumya cakulya muzuba
sun.culturalContext: Important celestial body in traditional Tonga cosmology and practical life, used for timing daily activities

examples: Today is a good day - Buzuba sunu mbubotu
I work during the day - Ndilabeleka muciindi cabuzuba
day.culturalContext: Basic unit of time in Tonga culture, with traditional activities organized around daylight hours

examples: The moon is bright tonight - Mwezi ulamunikisya sunu mansiku
The year has twelve months - Mwaka ulijisi myezi iili kkumi aibili
moon/month.culturalContext: Important celestial body used for traditional timekeeping and calendar systems in Tonga culture

examples: The drought killed our crops - Cimpayuma cakajaya zisyango zyesu
We pray for rain during drought - Tulakumba mvula muciindi cacimpayuma
drought.culturalContext: Serious environmental condition that has significant impact on Tonga agricultural communities

examples: The sun rises in the east - Zuba lilabuka kujwe
They live to the east of us - Bakkala kujwe kwesu
east.culturalContext: Cardinal direction associated with sunrise and used for orientation in traditional Tonga navigation

examples: The sun sets in the west - Zuba lilabbila kumbo
The market is to the west - Musika uli kumbo
west.culturalContext: Cardinal direction associated with sunset and used for orientation in traditional Tonga navigation

examples: The mountains are to the north - Zilundu zili kunyika
They traveled north - Bakayenda kunyika
north.culturalContext: Cardinal direction used for orientation in traditional Tonga navigation and spatial understanding

examples: The river is to the south - Mulonga uli kumusanzya
Wind blows from the south - Muwo ulaba kuzwa kumusanzya
south.culturalContext: Cardinal direction used for orientation in traditional Tonga navigation and spatial understanding

examples: I need to wash my clothes - Ndiyanda kusanzya zisani zyangu
These clothes are clean - Zisani ezi zilasalala
clothes.culturalContext: Traditional Tonga clothing has evolved with outside influences while maintaining certain cultural elements in ceremonial contexts

examples: I bought new trousers - Ndakaula buluke bupya
His trousers are torn - Buluke bwakwe bwadabuka
trousers.culturalContext: Introduced garment that has become standard male clothing, replacing traditional garments for everyday wear

examples: She is wearing a beautiful skirt - Wasamide munsisi mubotu
The skirt is long - Munsisi mulamfu
skirt.culturalContext: Common female garment that has evolved from traditional wraps to modern styles

examples: She bought a new dress - Wakaula delesi pya
The dress is beautiful - Delesi ndibotu
dress.culturalContext: Introduced female garment that has become common in everyday and formal wear

examples: I sleep under a blanket - Ndiloona kunsi angubo
The blanket is warm - Ngubo ilakasaala
blanket.culturalContext: Important household item, especially during cold season in Tonga communities

examples: I sleep on a bed - Ndiloona abulo
The bed is comfortable - Bulo bulalulama
bed.culturalContext: Traditional sleeping arrangements have evolved from mats on the floor to raised beds in many households

examples: I want to eat an orange - Ndiyanda kulya fuleenke
Oranges are sweet - Fuleenke zilatama
orange.culturalContext: Introduced fruit that has become common in Tonga communities and markets

examples: The guava is ripe - Gwaba lyadomeka
Children like eating guavas - Bana bayanda kulya gwaba
guava.culturalContext: Fruit that grows in many Tonga communities, often enjoyed by children who gather them from trees

examples: We cook pumpkin - Tulipika itanga
The pumpkin is big - Itanga ndipati
pumpkin.culturalContext: Important crop in traditional Tonga agriculture, with both fruit and leaves being consumed

examples: I am eating a cucumber - Ndilalya kkowa
The cucumber is fresh - Kkowa licipya
cucumber.culturalContext: Vegetable grown in many Tonga gardens and eaten fresh

examples: Add tomatoes to the soup - Yungizya madeede kusupu
The tomatoes are ripe - Madeede adomeka
tomato.culturalContext: Important ingredient in many modern Tonga dishes, though not native to the region

examples: Cut the onion - Kudumuna hanyisi
Onions make you cry - Hanyisi zilakudilisya misozi
onion.culturalContext: Common cooking ingredient in contemporary Tonga cuisine

examples: I want to eat meat - Ndiyanda kulya nyama
The meat is tender - Nyama ilalulama
meat.culturalContext: Valued food in Tonga culture, often reserved for special occasions in traditional contexts

examples: We cook pumpkin leaves - Tulipika bbobola
Pumpkin leaves are nutritious - Bbobola ulasani
pumpkin leaves.culturalContext: Traditional vegetable dish that is commonly consumed in Tonga communities

examples: Children like sweet cane - Bana bayanda munsale
The sweet cane is juicy - Munsale ulajisi mwata
sweet cane.culturalContext: Sweet treat enjoyed especially by children in rural Tonga communities

examples: I want to fulfill my promise - Ndiyanda kuzuzikizya cisyomezyo cangu
He fulfilled his duty - Wakazuzikizya mulimo wakwe
to fulfill.culturalContext: Concept related to responsibility and commitment in Tonga social values

examples: I like to read books - Ndiyanda kubala mabbuku
She is reading a letter - Ulabala lugwalo
to read.culturalContext: Literacy has become increasingly important in Tonga communities with formal education

examples: I am writing a letter - Ndilalemba lugwalo
He writes well - Ulalemba kabotu
to write.culturalContext: Literacy skill that has gained importance with education and modern communication

examples: I believe you - Ndilakusyoma
They believe in God - Balasyoma Leza
believe.culturalContext: Concept important in both traditional spiritual beliefs and adopted religious practices

examples: They will marry next year - Balakwatana mwaka uza
He married my sister - Wakakwata mucizi wangu
marry.culturalContext: Important life event in Tonga culture with specific traditions and ceremonies

examples: Don't intrude on their conversation - Utakwiingani muchimambulilo chabo
He intruded on our meeting - Wakiingana mumuswaangano wesu
to intrude.culturalContext: Social boundaries are important in Tonga culture, with intrusion considered impolite

examples: We lack water - Tulabula meenda
They lack money - Balabula mali
to lack.culturalContext: Concept related to resource scarcity which can be a challenge in rural Tonga communities

examples: They take care of orphans - Balikucita kabotu kumucaala
The child is an orphan - Mwana ngumucaala
orphan.culturalContext: Traditional Tonga culture has established support systems for orphans within extended family structures

examples: The dog is chasing the cat - Mubwa ulatanda mpuuzi
Don't chase the children - Utakutandi bana
to chase.culturalContext: Action that can occur in various contexts from play to hunting to conflict

examples: Stop shouting - Leka koompolola
They are shouting with joy - Balakoompolola alukondo
shouting.culturalContext: Can be considered rude in normal conversation but appropriate in certain contexts like celebrations

examples: He shoots animals - Uladubula banyama
Don't shoot - Utadubuli
to shoot.culturalContext: Action traditionally associated with hunting in Tonga culture

examples: They worship on Sunday - Balakomba nsondo
We worship God - Tulakomba Leza
to worship.culturalContext: Religious practice that has evolved from traditional spiritual practices to include Christian worship in many communities

examples: He is pleading for help - Ulakombelezya lugwasyo
Stop pleading - Leka kukombelezya
pleading.culturalContext: Communication style used in situations of great need or when seeking forgiveness

examples: I like to sing - Ndiyanda kwiimba
They are singing - Baliikwimba
to sing.culturalContext: Important cultural expression in Tonga traditions, featured in ceremonies, celebrations, and daily life

examples: I got lost in the forest - Ndakasweka musyoka
Don't get lost - Utasweki
to get lost.culturalContext: Potentially dangerous situation in rural settings, with traditional knowledge teaching navigation by landmarks and stars

examples: I like to dance - Ndiyanda kuzyana
They are dancing - Balazyana
dance.culturalContext: Important cultural expression in Tonga traditions, with specific dances for different ceremonies and occasions

examples: Hurry up! - Fwambaana!
We need to hurry - Tuleelede kufwambaana
hurry.culturalContext: The concept of hurrying has traditionally been less emphasized in rural Tonga life, which often follows natural rhythms

examples: Don't steal - Utakuubi
He stole money - Wakauba mali
to steal.culturalContext: Strongly discouraged in Tonga culture, which values honesty and respect for others' property

examples: Don't cheat in the exam - Utakweeni mucibbalo
He cheated in business - Wakaeena mubusamisi
to cheat/desire.culturalContext: Dishonesty is frowned upon in Tonga culture, which values integrity and truthfulness

examples: We must prevent disease - Tuleelede kukwabilila bulwazi
He prevented an accident - Wakakwabilila kukosya
to prevent.culturalContext: Preventive actions are valued in Tonga wisdom, which emphasizes foresight and caution

examples: The police confiscated illegal goods - Bamapulisa bakanyanga zintu zitazuminizigwi
Don't grab his things - Utakunyangi zintu zyakwe
to grab/repossess/confiscate.culturalContext: Action that can be seen as either enforcement of rules or violation of personal boundaries depending on context

examples: I want to give you a gift - Ndiyanda kukupa cipego
Give me water - Ndipe meenda
to give.culturalContext: Generosity is highly valued in Tonga culture, with gift-giving being an important part of social relationships

examples: Don't be pompous - Utalilisumpuli
He is too pompous - Ulalisumpula maningi
to be pompous.culturalContext: Humility is valued in traditional Tonga culture, with excessive self-importance viewed negatively

examples: The smoke makes me suffocate - Busi bulandifwundilila
He almost suffocated in the water - Wakali kunoofwundilila mumeenda
suffocate.culturalContext: Physical danger that can come from various environmental hazards

examples: I admire your work - Ndilakunyomenena mulimo wako
We admire good leaders - Tulanyomenena basololi babotu
to admire.culturalContext: Expression of respect for achievement, skill, or character in Tonga culture

examples: Be careful, they might swindle you - Kocenjela, batauninide
He swindled many people - Wakaunina bantu banji
to swindle.culturalContext: Dishonest practice strongly discouraged in Tonga ethical teachings

examples: Don't try to bribe officials - Utasooli kuulanamakulo bamulimo
He was caught bribing the police - Wakajatwa kaaulanamakulo bamapulisa
to bribe.culturalContext: Corruption practice that contradicts traditional Tonga values of fairness and integrity

examples: Please show mercy - Akutube alubomba
God's mercy is great - Lubomba lwa Leza ndupati
mercy.culturalContext: Important virtue in Tonga spiritual and ethical teachings, demonstrating compassion

examples: I want to help you - Ndiyanda kukugwasya
They help each other - Balagwasyana
to help.culturalContext: Central value in Tonga communities, which emphasize mutual aid and support

examples: I want to sell my cow - Ndiyanda kusambala ng'ombe yangu
She sells vegetables at the market - Ulasambala zisyu kumusika
to sell.culturalContext: Important economic activity in Tonga communities, with traditional and modern market systems

examples: He likes to photograph nature - Uyanda kufwotola bulenge
Can I photograph you? - Ndikufwotole?
to photograph.culturalContext: Modern introduced technology that has become common for documenting events and people

examples: Don't point at people - Utakutondeki bantu
He pointed at the mountain - Wakatondeka cilundu
to point at.culturalContext: In traditional Tonga culture, pointing at people with the index finger can be considered rude

examples: The child has shyness - Mwana ulijisi buusu
Overcome your shyness - Zunda buusu bwako
shyness.culturalContext: Personality trait that can be seen positively as modesty or negatively as inhibition

examples: It's good to be humble - Ncibotu kulomana
A leader should be humble - Musololi weelede kulomana
to be humble.culturalContext: Highly valued character trait in Tonga culture, especially for leaders and elders

examples: Don't beg for money - Utalombi mali
He is begging for forgiveness - Ulalomba kulekelela
to beg.culturalContext: Can be seen as either humble request or undignified depending on context

examples: Don't fear the dark - Utayoowi mudima
They fear punishment - Balayoowa cisubulo
to fear.culturalContext: Natural emotion acknowledged in Tonga wisdom, with teachings about appropriate and inappropriate fears

examples: Please explain this to me - Ndilomba kundipandululila ceeci
He explained the tradition - Wakapandulula cilengwa
explain.culturalContext: Important communicative action for teaching and sharing knowledge in Tonga culture

examples: Don't get embarrassed - Utasampuki
She got embarrassed when they mentioned her name - Wakasampuka nibakamba zina lyakwe
get embarrassed.culturalContext: Social emotion related to honor and reputation in community contexts

examples: He is ashamed of his actions - Ulagunwa azyintu nzyakacita
Don't be ashamed to ask questions - Utagunwi kubuzya mibuzyo
to be ashamed.culturalContext: Related to social norms and moral standards in Tonga culture

examples: Don't curse others - Utalsinganii bambi
Cursing is considered bad - Kasinganyo kalabonwa kubisya
to curse.culturalContext: Strongly discouraged in Tonga culture as it is believed to have spiritual consequences

examples: Don't hate your brother - Utazoondid mukulana wako
Hatred destroys communities - Kuzoonda kulajaigwa mbunga
to hate.culturalContext: Strong negative emotion discouraged in Tonga ethical teachings, which emphasize harmony

examples: Don't be anxious about tomorrow - Utayandisisyi juunza
She is anxious about the exam - Ulayandisisya acibbalo
to be anxious.culturalContext: Emotional state understood in relation to uncertainty and concerns about future events

examples: I love my family - Ndiyanda mukwasyi wangu
Do you like this food? - Sena ulayanda cakulya eeci?
to love/like.culturalContext: Central emotion in Tonga relationships, extending beyond romantic love to family and community bonds

examples: Don't insult the elders - Utakutukili baalu
Insulting others is disrespectful - Kutukila bambi taleetelelwi
to insult.culturalContext: Strongly discouraged in Tonga culture, which values respect, especially for elders

examples: This fruit is sweet - Muchelo oyu ulalweela
I like sweet food - Ndiyanda cakulya cilalweela
sweet.culturalContext: Taste that is generally enjoyed and associated with natural sweetness of fruits and honey in traditional context

examples: This medicine is bitter - Musamu oyu ulalula
Some vegetables are bitter - Zisyu zimwi zilalula
bitter.culturalContext: Taste often associated with traditional medicines and certain wild vegetables in Tonga culture

examples: She is beautiful - Uli mubotu
This is a beautiful house - Eyi ng'anda nja mubotu
beautiful/handsome.culturalContext: Aesthetic appreciation that extends beyond physical appearance to include character and behavior in Tonga conceptualization of beauty

examples: He is drunk - Wakolwa
Don't drink too much or you'll get drunk - Utanywi maningi nape ulakolwa
to be drunk/intoxicated.culturalContext: State traditionally associated with ceremonial or social drinking, though excessive intoxication is generally discouraged

examples: I like the orange color - Ndiyanda musyobo wa mukuba
The sunset is orange - Kutama kwajuba nkwamu musyobo wa mukuba
orange colour.culturalContext: Color associated with certain natural elements including sunsets and specific fruits

examples: I prefer black clothes - Ndiyanda zisani zyamusyobo uusiya
The night sky is black - Julu lifunga mumusyobo uusiya
black.culturalContext: Color with various associations including night, certain animals, and traditional items

examples: The blood is red - Bulowa bulamusyobo uusalala
She is wearing a red dress - Wasamide delesi lyamusyobo uusalala
red.culturalContext: Color with strong associations to blood, certain flowers, and traditional ceremonies

examples: The clouds are white - Makumbi alimusyobo uutuba
They painted the wall white - Bakapenta bulambo mumusyobo uutuba
white.culturalContext: Color often associated with purity, clouds, and certain ceremonial contexts in Tonga culture

examples: You have no money - Ku nyina mali iwi
He says you have no money - Waamba kuti ku nyina mali iwi
you have no money.culturalContext: Expression used to indicate lack of financial resources
you have no money.usage: Financial expression used in everyday conversation

examples: Get pregnant and get paid - Imita ufole
She wants to get pregnant and get paid - Uyanda ku imita ufole
get pregnant and get paid.culturalContext: Idiomatic expression related to compensation and pregnancy
get pregnant and get paid.usage: Colloquial phrase referring to benefits or compensation related to pregnancy

examples: This is my house - Iyi inganda yandi
I am going home - Ndiyenda kung'anda
house.culturalContext: Home and family are central to Tonga culture

examples: I am going to the shop - Ndiyenda kuchintolo
The shop is closed - Chintolo chakalala
shop.culturalContext: Trading and commerce are important in Tonga communities

examples: I am going to the market - Ndiyenda kumusika
The market is busy today - Musika uli na bantu lelo
market.culturalContext: Markets are social and economic hubs in Tonga communities

examples: I am going to church - Ndiyenda kuchikombelo
Church service starts at 9 - Chikombelo chikamba pa 9
church.culturalContext: Christianity plays an important role in Tonga communities

examples: I am going to the hospital - Ndiyenda kuchibadela
The hospital is far - Chibadela chili kule
hospital.culturalContext: Healthcare access is important in rural Tonga communities

examples: I am going to school - Ndiyenda kucikolo
School starts at 7 - Cikolo cikamba pa 7
school.culturalContext: Education is highly valued in Tonga culture

examples: The jungle is thick - Syokwe sili na miti
We walked through the jungle - Twalamba mwasyokwe
jungle.culturalContext: Forests and natural vegetation are part of the Tonga landscape

examples: The river has water- Mulonga uli na meenda
We crossed the river - Twalamba pamulonga
river.culturalContext: Rivers are important water sources and transportation routes

examples: The road is good - Nzila yalungama
I am walking on the road - Ndilamba panzila
road.culturalContext: Roads connect communities and enable travel
